cluster_classes.class_description: Steels that are prone to graphitization, a microstructural change causing loss of strength and ductility.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Graphitization affects carbon, 0.5Mo, and low alloy C-Mo steels.

members.entity_description: Steels that do not have alloying elements intentionally added, but may contain small amounts of elements and are affected by graphitization under certain conditions.
A type of steel that undergoes graphitization at elevated temperatures.
A type of steel susceptible to graphitization, especially with up to 1% Mo.

cluster_classes.class_description: Steels designed for high temperature applications, including low alloy and quenched and tempered types.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Used for high temperature strength and creep resistance.

members.entity_description: A type of steel used for thick wall reactor vessels in petroleum refinery processes.
Steels with up to 9% chromium and other alloys for high temperature strength and creep resistance.

cluster_classes.class_description: Processes involving the transformation of carbide phases into graphite nodules in steels at elevated temperatures.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Transformation of carbide phases into graphite nodules.

members.entity_description: Change in microstructure of carbon and 0.5Mo steels causing loss of strength and ductility.
Result of carbide phase decomposition in steels at elevated temperatures, forming graphite nodules.

cluster_classes.class_description: Chromium as an alloying element in steel, providing resistance to oxidation, corrosion, and eliminating graphitization.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Chromium is an alloying element in stainless steels.

members.entity_description: An alloying element in stainless steels that provides resistance to oxidation and corrosion.
Element added to steel to eliminate graphitization.

args.new_description: Steels designed for high temperature applications, including low alloy and quenched and tempered types.
args.justification: Class_Group 'Metallurgical Materials' is too broad and inconsistent with the other classes in this cluster, which all relate to steel metallurgy and degradation; aligning Class_Group improves schema connectivity.

args.new_description: Chromium as an alloying element in steel, providing resistance to oxidation, corrosion, and eliminating graphitization.
args.justification: Chromium's role is specifically in the context of steel metallurgy and graphitization prevention, so assigning to 'Steel Metallurgy and Degradation' Class_Group is appropriate.

splits.name: Graphitization (Process)
splits.description: The process of carbide phase transformation into graphite nodules in steels at elevated temperatures.

splits.name: Graphite Nodules (Product)
splits.description: Graphite nodules formed as a result of graphitization in steels.

args.justification: The class 'Graphitization Phenomena' is overloaded, containing both the process (graphitization) and its product (graphite nodules), which are distinct concepts and should be separated for schema clarity.

executed_decisions.new_description: Steels designed for high temperature applications, including low alloy and quenched and tempered types.
executed_decisions.justification: Class_Group 'Metallurgical Materials' is too broad and inconsistent with the other classes in this cluster, which all relate to steel metallurgy and degradation; aligning Class_Group improves schema connectivity.

executed_decisions.new_description: Chromium as an alloying element in steel, providing resistance to oxidation, corrosion, and eliminating graphitization.
executed_decisions.justification: Chromium's role is specifically in the context of steel metallurgy and graphitization prevention, so assigning to 'Steel Metallurgy and Degradation' Class_Group is appropriate.

The class 'Graphitization Phenomena' is overloaded, containing both the process (graphitization) and its product (graphite nodules), which are distinct concepts and should be separated for schema clarity.
